Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploring Extreme-Scale DNA-based Storage Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Civilization increasingly relies on computer technology and access to large databases of searchable information for all facets of life, with the world's digital data projected to exceed 16 zettabytes in 2017. However, long-term, reliable storage of this vast amount of digital data greatly exceeds the capacity of any computer system even when accounting for expected advances in the storage industry. Extraordinary breakthroughs in storage technology are needed.

DNA offers a potentially transformative solution due to its high raw capacity of 1 zettabyte per cubic centimeter. To put that in perspective, the best technology available today would require 100,000 cubic meters of volume to store the equivalent amount of information. If successful as a storage medium, DNA could hold the world?s entire digital data in a relatively small volume.

This project's key objectives are to quantify the limitations imposed by the properties of DNA on extreme storage systems, and to engineer solutions to surpass them. To enable reliable exabyte capacities, this proposal specifically focuses on new and transformative approaches to encode data in DNA that require both developing and harnessing a deeper understanding of the chemo-physical characteristics of DNA. Interestingly, extreme DNA storage systems cannot yet be synthesized using existing technologies, yet their properties must be studied to motivate and inform their development. To achieve this, a computationally and experimentally simulated extreme capacity model system will be developed that can be used to study pertinent properties.

The project is lead by an expert in computer systems, and an expert in molecular biology and DNA manipulation and processing. The team will apply a highly coordinated combination of computer systems theory and design, simulation, and molecular biology experiments to address critical barriers to high-capacity DNA storage. This project will support the training of two Ph.D. students in the area of DNA-based Storage Systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DNA has compelling potential as a digital storage medium, but to achieve scalability to extreme capacities, many advances are still needed. Many previous works either did not support random access of data from a large library of DNA or could only access relatively few unique files.  This is a consequence of using a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to select and copy only some DNA strands. For PCR to work, each strand needs a relatively unique sequence at the beginning and end of the strand, called a primer sequence, that allows it to be differentiated from other strands. Unfortunately, there are relatively few of these unique sequences, on the order of thousands, that work well together, and this limits system capacity and density. Furthermore, PCR relies on extracting some of the DNA from the library for replication.  This limits the number of times data can be accessed.  PCR also requires heating the DNA so that double-stranded DNA is melted into single strands that allow each strand to be copied.  This repetitive heating and extraction process poses multiple challenges both in terms of energy and reliability, and also it means that the data payload needs to be designed to be sufficiently different from the primer sequences so that the primers only match the beginning and end of strands. It also implies a relatively static way of using files, for example, they can not be renamed or erased easily.

 

To solve the challenge of limited capacity that results from a few unique primer sequences, a system called DENSe was designed that nests multiple primers on each strand. This allows us to uniquely access a file based on a combination of primer sequences, thereby increasing the capacity of the system by orders of magnitude. A sequence of PCR steps was designed and experimentally demonstrated to extract strands associated with a specific primer combination from a terabyte-scale database. As a result, DENSe enables an estimated six-orders of magnitude higher capacity and more selective access of data than previously possible.  DENSe has been implemented and demonstrated experimentally.

 

To overcome some of the other limitations of PCR and to enable a more sustainable and dynamic DNA-based file system, Dynamic Operations and Reusable Information Storage, or DORIS for short, was developed. Instead of using double-stranded DNA, DORIS uses double-stranded DNA with a single-stranded overhang that sticks off the end of each strand.  The overhang offers a set of rich dynamic operations. One opportunity is to attach a new sequence to the overhang to rename the file or to lock the file from further access. The overhang also improves access and separation and does not require PCR. The overhang can be used to extract the strands using a complementary sequence attached to a magnetic bead. The extracted DNA is then transcribed into RNA for separation. Since RNA can be distinguished from DNA, the RNA can be separated from the stored library and the extracted DNA returned to the library. As a result, DORIS does not incur the same loss of data as prior systems. Lastly, the extracted RNA can be transcribed back to DNA for sequencing and decoding.  Finally, since DORIS does not use PCR as the basis for extraction, DORIS can work at room temperature, making it more feasible to develop DNA data management technologies that are viable in real-world scenarios. Altogether, DORIS enables a more advanced and richer set of primitives for DNA-based storage. DORIS has been implemented and demonstrated experimentally.

 

The key findings of the DENSE and DORIS systems, along with other findings of the project, have been published in two journal articles and two patent applications. In total, 12 students, including 3 Ph.D. students, 1 M.S. student, and 7 undergraduates, and 1 high school student, received training on this project in inter-disciplinary topics spanning the fields of synthetic biology, chemical engineering, and computer engineering.
